Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…
speaker: Alice

text: And I'm Neil.
Can you do any impersonations, Neil?
speaker: Alice

text: Hmm. How about this one?
My name is Michael Cain.
Not a lot of people know that.
speaker: catchphrase

text: Hmm, Michael Cain, one of our best loved actors here in Britain.
Not bad, Neil.
speaker: impersonation

text: And it's a very good way to start today's show.
We are talking about impersonation
or the act of pretending to be somebody else.
Why do we like impersonations, Neil?
Well, sometimes the impersonator is a comedian
and doing it to be funny.
But another reason is that we get the opportunity to meet people
who are no longer with us,
like Elvis Presley or Marilyn Monroe.
Either way, it helps if it's a good impersonation.
Yes, some impersonations are pretty cheesy
speaker: cheesy

text: and that means bad quality.
Oh yeah, sure.
Uh-huh.
Okay, Alice.
I have a question for you.
Neil, that's terrible!
speaker: Alice

text: Elvis, please, come on.
Can you tell me the name of a musical act
that impersonates a famous group?
speaker: Alice

text: Is it a, tribute,
b, tribune,
speaker: Neil

text: or c) tribunal?
speaker: Neil

text: I'll go for a, tribute.
A tribute act?
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, well, we'll find out if you got that right later on in the show.
But, Alice, don't you think some impersonators start to believe
they really are the personalities they imitate?
What makes you say that?
Well, just think.
every time you appear as Elvis Presley
speaker: Neil

text: you get fans yelling,
Elvis, Elvis, we love you, Elvis.
And after a while, that boundary between you and the real Elvis
starts to blur.
It must be quite tempting to, you know, pretend that you're
looking at rock and roll.
I'm not convinced, Neil.
I think Elvis hangs up his wig and moves on.
So, let's move on to and talk about the art of imitation.
Here's British Impressionist John Kulture providing some tips on how to imitate
or copy people.
Don't just say the catchphrase
speaker: INSERT

text: Don't just say, I am Michael Cain.
Say a bit more.
Get some gags going, some conversation going.
Notice the things which are worth stretching,
which are worth exaggerating to really give you the caricature
of that person.
It might be a little tick.
It might be a little nuance.
Whatever you notice first, really.
John Kulture there.
What's a catchphrase, Neil?
It's a well-known phrase often associated with a famous person,
like the one I used for Michael Cain earlier on.
Not a lot of people know that.
So, John is saying that it isn't enough to repeat a catchphrase
or use another impersonator's ideas.
You need to think of your own gags or jokes.
And you do this by noticing and then exaggerating a person's tics.
speaker: tic

text: A tick is something you do often without realizing you're doing it,
like using certain phrases or gestures,
for example, scratching your head or in your case, Neil,
wiggling your eyebrows.
Do I wiggle my eyebrows?
You're doing it right now!
speaker: impostors

text: But moving on, there is a serious and very negative side to impersonation.
Some imposter's, or people who deceive others by pretending to be somebody else,
poses doctors or lawyers, for example.
You mean without having the qualifications to do the job?
Exactly
speaker: Alice

text: Which can have serious consequences,
for example, pretending to be a doctor with no medical knowledge.
Ah, like in that film with Leonardo DiCaprio,
where his character impersonates an airline pilot,
a doctor and a lawyer.
DiCaprio's character in the movie Catch Me If You Can
speaker: Alice

text: is actually based on a real man called Frank Abagnale.
Panam estimated that in two years, Abagnale flew 250 flights to 26 countries.
Okay, let's listen to Dr. Nath Talley-Gberal, a forensic psychologist in New York City.
He evaluates people for the American government.
Here he's talking about another real case of a woman in the US
who was caught pretending to be an attorney.
That's a lawyer.
The thing that was most troubling is that
speaker: Dr Naftali G. Berrill, forensic psychologist in New York City

text: because she realized that she was not an attorney,
and that she was taking people's money under false pretence,
there was no sense of remorse or a sense of sadness
that she'd exploited the people that trusted her.
But, you know, in cases where you get these imposter's
who specifically are pursuing financial gain,
they know what they're doing,
but they do it with the shallow conscience
of an anti-social personality.
That was Dr. Nath Talley-Gberal.
What does remorse mean, Neil?
It means being sorry for something you've done.
speaker: Neil

text: And our conscience is our inner sense of right or wrong,
so a shallow conscience is one that isn't very deep.
Anti-social in this context means harmful to other people and to society.
Although in a general sense, it means not enjoying the company of others.
Hmm, okay.
Well, I love your company, Neil, as you know.
Now, how about the answer to today's quiz question?
I asked, what's the name we use for a band that impersonates a famous group?
Is it a tribute, b tribute or c tribunal?
I said tribute.
speaker: Alice

text: And you were right.
Three.
Many tribute acts copy the singing style and the appearance of the group
speaker: Alice

text: as well as playing their music.
They often name themselves based on the original band's name,
sometimes with a pun, or on one of their songs or albums.
For example, Björn again, a famous Aber tribute band.
This name is a pun on Björn, a member of Aber,
and the phrase born again, which means to come back to life.
Hmm, okay.
It's time to hear the words we learned today
speaker: Alice
